loans.name: Margot

texts.es: Margot S. es una socia muy trabajadora y alegre, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 31 años, madre de dos hijos menores de edad, Margot se dedica a la venta de repuestos de motos y motocarro, este negocio funciona en su casa, trabaja junto a su esposo, el cual es mecánico. Integra el Banco Comunal “Las Nazarenas” desde hace tres años, el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que invirtió en víveres para preparar comida, para luego vender a sus clientes. Ahora Margot necesita un crédito de 1700 soles que invertirá en el taller de motos que tiene en su casa. La meta de Margot es tener una tienda de prendas de vestir y seguir trabajando para aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Margot is a happy, hard working woman who lives in the town of Pucallpa, located in the Ucayali region. She is 31 years old and the mother of two young children. Margot sells spare parts for motorcycles and small three wheeled motorized vehicles called " motocarros." She and her husband, who is also a mechanic, run their business out of their home. She has been a part of the “Las Nazarenas" communal bank for three years. Her first loan was for 300 PEN (~$100), which she invested in supplies for preparing food which she then sold to her customers. Margo needs a loan for 1700 PEN ($600) which she will invest into her repair business. Her goal is to someday have her own clothing store and continue working to increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in additional inventory

loans.name: Rebeca Hermelinda

texts.es: La Señorita Rebeca es originaria de la comunidad del cantón Chiyax del Municipio de Totonicapan comenta la señorita Rebeca cuando ella tenia ocho años  cuando aprendio el arte como trabajadora con la señora Maria Gutierrez, ella aprendio el dicho trabajo, cuando cumplio quince años decio iniciar su propio negocio, con un capital de dos mil quetzales, día a día lucha para poder incrementar su negocio hoy necesita de un credito que sera utilizado en la compra de tela conos,forros. para poder satisfacer la necesidad de sus cliente principalmente en la época de navidad, y el inicio del ciclo escolar dos mil diez para el uniforme de las niñas.
texts.en:
Señorita Rebeca is from the Chiyax community in the town of Totonicapan. She says that she was eight years old when she learned her craft, working with Señora Maria Gutierrez. At fifteen years of age, having mastered her trade, she started her own business with capital of 2,000 quetzales. Day by day she strives to grow her business. She currently needs a loan to buy fabrics and linings to better satisfy her clients' needs during the holiday period, and also for the girls' uniforms for the start of the 2010 school year.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics

loans.name: Leobardo

texts.es:
El señor Leobardo C. esta muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual le ayudo mucho a su negocio.
Nueva mente está solicitando un préstamo para poder comprar mercancía de temperado ya que tiene muy poco inventario y esta temporada es una de las mejores ventas que hay, es por eso que quiere invertirle al negocio. 
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias de la inversión, ya que los gastos familiares se cubrirán con la pensión que recibe.
texts.en:
Leobardo C. is very grateful for his last loan which helped him a lot with his business. He is asking for another loan to buy seasonal merchandise as he has very little inventory and this season is one of the best for sales. Because of this, he wants to invest in his business now.

He plans to pay back his loan with the earnings from his business, because his household expenses will be covered by the pension he receives.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying merchandise

loans.name: Catarina  Marisela

texts.es: La Señorita Marisela Y. Y. es originaria  de la comunidad de chiya es un lugar muy visitado por los turistas nacionales e internacionales por las cuevas de San Miguel ella inicio la señorita aprendio el arte de la sastreria  en las maquilas de san Lucas Sacatepequez Guatemala  hace tres años inicio su propio negocio en  la elaboración de gabachas para damas y uniformes de las niñas y señorita hoy necesita del apoyo de la institucion ASDIR para un credito que lo invertira en la compra de tela por motivo que tiene un encargo de uniforme de una escuela de su comunidad
texts.en:
Ms. Marisela Y. Y. is from the community of Chiya. It is a place visited frequently by national and international tourists because of the caves of San Miguel. She learned the art of tailoring in the assembly plants of San Lucas Sacatepequez, Guatemala. Three years ago, she started her own business in the production of ladies' aprons and girls' uniforms. Today she needs the support of the ASDIR institution for a loan which she will invest in the purchase of fabric, because she has an order for uniforms from a community school.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital Increase

loans.name: Pablo

texts.es:
A la vivienda del señor Pablo M. le está haciendo falta los acabados del exterior y empezar la elaboración de un cuarto.
Solicita el préstamo ya que en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder terminar su casa y empezar la construcción de un cuarto más será para uno de sus hijos que ya están creciendo y quieren su propio espacio en la casa.
Don Pablo tiene un carro de taxi el cual trabaja con el todo el día y con el cual una parte de las ganancias será para pagar el crédito.
La persona que aparece en la foto es la señora Santa Isabel Pérez esposa el señor Pablo, ya que el se encontraba en su trabajo el día de la visita.
texts.en:
Señor Pablo M.'s house needs the outside finished off and another room added. He is asking for a loan as he does not currently have enough money to finish off his house and start building a room for one of his children who are growing up and want their own space in the house. Don Pablo works all day long with his taxi cab and he will use some of that income to pay off the loan. The woman in the photo is Señora Santa Isabel Pérez, Señor Pablo's wife, as he was out at work on the day of the visit.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To finish the outside of the house and start building another room

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl C. is from the city of Santa Cruz, Tangub City. She is 26 years old. Sheryl is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Sheryl owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Sheryl has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sheryl joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheryl has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Sheryl is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Sheryl from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Yem

texts.en: Yem S., 40, is married with two school-aged children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. To make a living, she is engaged in selling fish at a local market in the town, earning an income of US $7 per day. Her husband helps his wife in the business, and he is also employed as a construction builder, earning an income of US $4 per day. These sources of income help S. and her husband cover the family's expenses. S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $1,000 to purchase rice from the local farmers in her province for resale.

loans.use: To buy rice for resale

loans.name: Chen

texts.en: Chen S., 25, is married with three children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband (pictured) and children. To make a living, she is engaged in the business of selling gasoline in her town, earning an income of US $4 per day. Her husband helps his wife in the business, and he is also a bike repairman, earning an income of US $5 per day. These sources of income help S. and her husband cover the family's expenses. S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $700 to purchase bikes and spare parts for resale.

loans.use: To buy bikes and spare parts for resale

loans.name: Samnang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Samnang S. is the group leader of four members who all live in Angk Svay Chek village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. She is a 21-year-old widow with a child.

Mrs. Samnang S.’s family living is not better because she is able to earn only a little income. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Samnang S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a bicycle plus some fish to resell to earn more income. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s standard of living with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a bicycle plus some fish to resell

loans.name: Sokha's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha B. is a group leader of four members who all live in Chrouy Chrey village in Kandal province. She is 37 years old and single.

Mrs. Sokha B. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. On her plantation she faces an obstacle because her field is infertile and this has a bad effect on her crops. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Sokha B. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the rice field to make the crop more productive. She will share this loan with the other group members.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en: Juanita N. is from the town of Lebueg Laoac, Pangasinan. She is 47 years old, married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Juanita runs a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, her main source of income is selling a variety of different products in the local community. Juanita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2009, Juanita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be Juanita's first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the product offering in her general store.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ny's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Ny M. is a group leader of four members who all live in Toek Klang village in Kandal province. He is 36 years old and the father of three children, two of whO. are enrolled in the local school while the other is too young to work or study.

My. Ny M. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates both rice and vegetables. His wife, Mrs. Chhorn Chamroeun, is a pig breeder. Since her breeding pigs business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, Mr. Ny M. is requesting a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. He will share this loan with the other members of his group.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Imylenda

texts.en: Imylenda H. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Imylenda owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling dried fish as well as ready-to-wear items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Imylenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Bit's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Bit K. is the group leader of four members who all live in Srae Chheu Neang village in Takeo province. He is a taxi driver.

His wife, Mrs. Chay Sary, is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, she is a duck-egg seller. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it.

Mr. Bit K. decided to ask for a loan to buy duck eggs to hatch. He is 35 years old and the father of a child who is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy duck eggs to hatch

loans.name: Khoeurn's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Khoeurn S. is a group leader of four members who all live in Krang Sbaek village in Takeo province. She is a salt middleman. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more salt to resell and earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Pang Phoeun, is a farmer who owns a 2-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. This couple do not have any children yet. Mrs. Chhroek Khan, is a group member and she also presented in the group loan.

loans.use: By purchasing more salt to resell to earn more income.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria B. is from the town of Lebueg Laoac, Pangasinan. She is 58 years old. Gloria is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Gloria owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gloria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita K. is from the village of Casinglot,  Tagoloan, in Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Angelita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Angelita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. loans.name: Foai

texts.en:
Foai is 29 and married with 3 children (ages 3-7).  She owns & operates a business venture, catching & selling farm-raised fish .  She has 4 years of experience in this business.    Foai needs a loan of WST $2700 to purchase a fishing boat.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 550 talas or US $229 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

In 2006, Foai joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Foai's 4th loan with SPBD. 

In addition, SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress.  The overall social metric score is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation.  A higher number represents a higher score.  For example, a "3 out of 3" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a "2 out of 3" = secondary/high-school, and a "1 out of 3" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.  

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

Foai's Overall Social Metric Score:*               1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD:
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.name: Garamsuren

texts.en:
O. Garamsuren is 40 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His three boys, ages 13 to 17, all attend a local secondary school.

Garamsuren operates a shoe-making business in his town with the help of his wife. He makes variety of European and traditional Mongolian shoes. Garamsuren started his business in 1995 in a small room which he still rents today. He has built up a stable business over the years and has become an experienced shoe-maker. Today, his business is growing rapidly and he recently hired two more assistants to keep up with demand. For the future, he says, “I hope to one day own my own workplace.” Garamsuren is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase tools and instruments for his shoe-making business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

Her older son is a university student, her younger is in high school and her husband works as a taxi driver. Boldmaa operates a small hair salon in her town. She opened her business in 1997 in partnership with a close friend. She and her friend, who is also a hairdresser, started their business out of a small rented workspace.

Over the years, Boldmaa has grown her business into a successful and stable operation. In 2005, she used her savings to buy her own workplace. At this time she also gave her salon a name, "HANA". She has continued her success since 2005 and has since hired four more hairdressers to keep up with demand.

Boldmaa works hard to provide quality service to her many customers and hopes to continue her success in the future. She is requesting a 2,245,000 tugrug (~1580 USD) loan to purchase styling equipment and supplies for her salon.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
A. Byambasuren is 44 years old and lives with his family in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. They live together in a 'ger', which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. He and his wife have six children, ages 4 to 22, the oldest of whom is in college. His wife operates a mobile food service and leather painting business.

Bayambasuren operates a jewelry-making business in his town. He makes a variety of gold and silver jewelry for his many customers. Bayambasuren started his business in 1998 in a small rented workspace. He has built up a stable operation over the years and has become a skilled jewelry crafter. His business is very important to him and he says, “ I am working hard because I have many mouths to feed.”

Byambasuren hopes to continue his success in the future and hopes to save enough to one day own his own workplace. He is requesting an 850,000 tugrug (~598 USD) loan to purchase jewelry decorating materials for his business.

About XacBank

loans.name: Davaasuren

texts.en: Z. Davaasuren is 33 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Zavkhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her oldest two children both attend a local secondary school and her husband operates a transportation service. Davaasuren operates a beauty salon in her town with the help of a couple of her close friends. She started her business in 2006, at first only selling beauty products. She had quick success with the beauty products and used her savings to open her salon earlier this year. Today her business continues to grow quickly and she is already thinking about expanding. Her earnings have enabled her to begin construction on a new house for her family. She says, “I want to be able to support my children's education and raise them to become good people.” Davaasuren is requesting a 800,000 tugrug (about $560 US) loan to purchase tools and supplies for her salon. loans.name: Tolusefulutasi

texts.en:
Tolusefulutasi is 45 and married with 6 children (ages 3 - 25).  She owns & operates a business venture, selling fine mats to tourists and local community members.  Fine mats are special in Samoan culture--they are not used to sit upon but to exchange as keepsakes for special occasions or future falavelave (family obligations such as funerals, weddings, etc.).  Tulusefulutasi has 3 years of experience in this business.    Tolusefulutasi needs a loan of WST $2700 to purchase raw materials to make mats & mattresses.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2006, Tolusefulutasi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Tolusefulutasi's 4th loan with SPBD. 

In addition, SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress.  The overall social metric score is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation.  A higher number represents a higher score.  For example, a "3 out of 3" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a "2 out of 3" = secondary/high-school, and a "1 out of 3" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.  

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

Tolusefulutasi's Overall Social Metric Score:               1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD:
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375
